p: Unprecedented and coordinated responses are required of many disparate actors, from national governments, and international organisations to civil society and individual researchers/practitioners in order to help vulnerable populations adapt to the adverse impacts of climate change (Bryson 2004; Ostrom 2010a). Invariably, the objectives, motives and actions of these actors are incompatible or misaligned with the goal of effective adaptation to climate change, leading to ill-defined and weak responses (Chaudhury et al. 2016b; Mermet 2011). Capturing the different motives, perception, and roles of these many actors under a unified framework is a major challenge (Etzion et al. 2015), but necessary to develop effective climate change adaptation strategies and plans for agricultural systems.
